MYTHS

 				 - -Export Import Knowledge\
International trade is the exchange of capital, goods, and services across international borders or territories. It is the exchange of goods and services among nations of the world. In most countries, such trade represents a significant share of gross domestic product (GDP). While international trade has existed throughout history (for example Uttarapatha, Silk Road, Amber Road, salt roads), its economic, social, and political importance has been on the rise in recent centuries.
Modes of transportation
	 - Sea-freight
 				 - Containerized, Full Container Load (FCL) / Less- than-full Container Load (LCL)
 				 - Conventional (general cargo)
 				 - Charter Shipping (bulk)
 				 - Roll on (RO)/Roll off (RO) Vessels and LASHING
 	 - Airfreight
 	 - Overland / Truck / Rail
 	 - Post
 	 - Multimodal Transportation

Selection of the Methods of Dispatch
	 - Rule of thumb
 				 - Relatively high value / low volume: use airfreight
 				 - Relatively low value / high volume: use sea freight
 	 - Type of supplies
 	 - Geography
 	 - Time element
 	 - Cost
 	 - Safety
 	 - Weight and Volume

Sea Freight
	 - Sea-Freight Containerized
 				 - Full Container Load (FCL): It is a “door to door” concept.
 				 - Less than a Container Load (LCL): It is a “Terminal to Terminal” concept.
 	 - Sea-Freight Conventional Cargo (General Cargo)
 	 - Sea-Freight Chartering
 	 - Sea-Freight Roll on / Roll off (RO/RO)
 	 - Sea-Freight LASH (Lighter Aboard Ship)

Method of quoting freight rates
	 - Case: Assuming that an ocean carrier or a freight consolidator offers an exporter $65 W/M (weight or measurement) for the shipment of 665 cartons of product DX. The specified weight is per 1,000 kg and measure is per cubic meter (m³). The gross weight of each carton is 10.5 kg and the dimensions are 0.45 x 0.30 x 0.30 m (LxWxH) which is 0.04 m³ per carton.
 	 - The consignment has a weight of 6,982.5 kg (i.e., 10.5 kg x 665) and a measure of 26.30 m³ (i.e., 0.04m³ x 665)
 	 - The freight cost by weight is: $65 x (6,982.5/1,000) = $ 453.86
 	 - The freight cost by measurement is: $65 x 26.30 = $ 1,729.00
 	 - The volume of product DX is large in relation to its weight; the freight cost by volume gives the carrier or the consolidator a higher revenue and thus the exporter pays $1,729,00

Air Freight
	 - Used for high value/low volume shipments.
 	 - Benefits of air freight:
 				 - Faster delivery
 				 - Better security
 				 - Less packaging
 				 - Lower insurance

Calculating Airfreight
	 - The basis of calculation of airfreight charges is normally weight per kilo, the weight being rounded off to the nearest higher 0.5 kg. When the ratio between weight and measurement exceeds 6, however (in the UK, it is 5), the basis for calculating cost will be on volumetric weight.
 Example:
 				 - A 9.8 kg package – volume 40 cm3 = charged at 10.0 kg
 				 - A 9.8 kg package – volume 75 cm3 = charged at 75/6 = 12.5 kg
 	 - Chargeable Weight for a shipment is the greater of the actual weight and the volumetric weight. It is proper and customary for the figure to be rounded up to the next 0.5 kg.

Calculating Airfreight -1
Shipment 1
 	 - Gross weight =750kgs
 	 - Measurement of cargo = 102cm X 98cm X 106cm = 1 box
 	 - 80cm X 65cm X 103cm = 3 boxes
 	 - Total volume = 1059576 + (535600X3) = 2666376 cubic centimeter
 	 - Total chargeable weight = 2666376 / 6000 = 444.396kgs
 	 - Here in shipment No: 1, the gross weight is 750kgs and chargeable weight is 444.396kgs. Hence, actual gross weight of 750kgs (which is greater) is charged airfreight.

Calculating Airfreight -2
Shipment 2
 	 - Gross weight = 850kgs
 	 - Measurement of cargo = 120cm X 160cm X 115cm = 2 boxes
 	 - 75cm X 130cm X 125cm = 2 boxes
 	 - Total volume = 4416000 + 2437500 = 6853500 cubic centimeter
 	 - Total chargeable weight = 6853500 / 6000 = 1142.25kgs
 	 - Here in shipment No:2, the gross weight is 850kgs and chargeable weight is 1142.25kgs. Hence, airfreight is charged on the basis of chargeable weight of 1142.25kgs. 
 Calculating Airfreight -3
Shipment 3
 	 - Gross weight : 950kgs.
 	 - Measurement of cargo = 1 meter X 1.05 meter X 0.85 meter = 2 boxes
 	 - 0.7 meter X 1.50 meter X 0.60 meter= 3 boxes
 	 - Total volume = (0.8925 X 2) + ( 0.63 X 3)
 	 - 1.785 + 1.89 = 3.675 cubic meter
 	 - Total chargeable weight = 3.675 / .006 = 612.50kgs

Other modes
	 - Overland (Truck/Rail)
 	 - Post
 	 - Multimodal Transportation
 					 - An example of multimodal transportation: Containers loaded in ICD Ahmedabad travel by train to Mumbai, then ship on a vessel to Dar-Es-Salaam, then are delivered inland in Tanzania by truck.

Packing
	 - Packing
 	 - Kind of product
 	 - Mode of transportation
 	 - Route and final destination
 	 - Climatic conditions
 	 - Customs duties and freight rates
 	 - Cost of packing materials
 	 - Pallets

Markings
	 - Markings or Known as “shipping marks”
 	 - It is preferable to replace ‘Marks’ with ‘Symbols’ such as the broken glass for fragile items or arrows for a package to be kept upright.
 	 - Example
 				Identification of the consignee				 UNDP
 				Destination 				 ADDIS ABABA
 				Port of unloading 				 VIA ASSAB
 				Project identification 				 HH/…/…
 				Order number 				 XO/ETH-1234/…
 				Case number 				 1/10…2/10…3/10

Addresses
	 - While shipping marks are usually abbreviated designations of the consignee and its location, the full address is written on shipping documents, as well as the address to which correspondence and shipping documents will be sent.

Parties Involved in the Chain of Transport
	 - Carriers
 				 - Inland carrier can be either rail or road transport, or often a combination of both.
 				 - Overseas carriers are either shipping or airline companies.
 	 - Forwarding Agents/Forwarders
 	 - Dock Authorities
 	 - Customs Authorities
 	 - Insurers
 	 - Others: container handling, warehousing/stevedoring, lighterage services, tally clerks, surveyors, banks, etc.

Why Exports?
	 - Increases the sales and profits of company,
 	 - Enables company to benchmark with their competitors and know their strategies and what they have done to increase their market share globally,
 	 - Reduces the risk of market fluctuations by depending on many markets,
 	 - Diminishes unit cost by adopting mass production strategy,
 	 - Enhances firms and countries’ competitive advantage by gaining new technologies,
 	 - Support countries' balance of trade.

Export Process
	 - Identify Country
 	 - Identify Buyer
 	 - Send Sample/Offer
 	 - Engage Buyer
 	 - Meet Specifications
 	 - Ask for order

What buyer wants?
	 - Fair price
 	 - Honor fundamentals of agreement
 	 - Value added or Branded or specified products
 	 - Quality products & consistency in quality
 	 - On time shipment
 	 - Longtime business relationship
 	 - Trust is the thread which connects all people!

	 - ICC (Int. Chamber of Commerce - The WBO)

 	 - UNCITRAL (United Nations Commission on International Trade Law)
 	 - WIPO (World Intellectual Property Organization)
 	 - Institute of International Commercial Law (Pace)
 	 - Lex Mercatoria

Various Rules & Acts
	 - Foreign Trade (Development and Regulation) Act, 1992
 	 - FTP (Export and Import (EXIM) Policy) 
 	 - FEMA 1999
 	 - The Central Excise Act 1944 http://www.cbec.gov.in/excise/cx-act/cx-act-idx.htm

Career Opportunities
	 -The following are the areas where students get employment:
 	 - Executives in Documentation, 
 	 - Custom House Agents,
 	 - Shipping Executives, 
 	 - Port Executives,
 	 - All type of manufacturing concerns,
 	 - ExIm Consultancy, etc.

Challenge
	 - A key challenge exporters face is the scarcity of reliable trade intelligence on markets.
 	 - Exporters need to stay abreast of 
 				 - competitive conditions in their current markets, 
 				 - scan opportunities for new or emerging markets,
 				 - look for opportunities to diversify or value-add to your existing product range.

//Payment Terms
Payment Terms
	 - Payment terms depend on the credit standing of the importer i.e. buyer and exporter (Seller).
 	 - Today’s International Trade & competition is no longer confined only to price, quality or delivery schedule, but payment term as well.
 	 - More export orders come due to attractive payment terms.

Tyeps of Payment Terms
	 - Advance
 		 - Under Export:-
 				 - Supplier can call advance payment for export. The export is required to be made with one year time period. If the same could not be done, advance can be returned to buyer with interest at LIBOR prevailing on date of refund plus 2%. Seller is allowed to send documents directly to buyer in case of 100% advance received.
 				 - LIBOR IS LONDON INTERBANK OFFERING RATE
	 - At sight (L/C) / DP (Document against payment) / CAD (Cash against document)
 		 - Purpose for all above is same. Under this term documents are delivered to buyer against payment only.
 		 - DP vs. DAP
 				 - Term ‘DP’ must not be used as ‘DAP’. ‘DP’ is a payment term and ‘DAP’ is shipping term.
 		 - CAD (Cash against document)
 				 - It is an old usage.
 				 - This is still commonly used.
 		 - Risk involved (Under collection document under CAD)
 				 - Buyer may or may not release documents

	 - Usance / DA (documents against acceptance)
 		 - Here some Credit period is allowed for payment to buyer. Under this buyer accepts bills of exchange to pay on maturity date. i.e. some days from date of shipment / bill of lading or invoice or exchange or any fixed date as agreed etc.
 		 - Under DA documents
 				 - Bank presents bills of exchange to buyer. Buyer signs bills of exchange in token of acceptance to pay on due date. Bank deliver documents to buyer.
 		 - Risk involved (under collection document)
 				 - This is very high risk. Bank has no responsibility to pay if buyer refuses to pay. Bank merely will hand over bill of exchange to seller for their furtherance. 
 				 - As far as risk is involved, this is not at all recommended for new exporter.

	 - Deferred (more than one type or types)
 		 - An arrangement in which the buyer is allowed to make partial payments i.e. more than one time in future dates.
 		 - For example :
 				- - 50% at sight,
 				 - 30% at 30 days from date of shipment and 
 				 - 20% balance at 60 days from date of shipment, etc.

Other type of Payment :
	 - Free of Cost – allowed up to Rs.5 lacs for non-status Holders and Rs.10 lacs for Status holders.
 	 - Status holders
 				- - Export House 		 - 20
 				- - Star Export House 		 - 100
 				- - Trading House 		 - 500
 				- - Star Trading House 		 - 2500
 				- - Premier Trading House 		 - 7500 and Above

//Identifying Buyers
Identifying Buyers
	 - There are two ways available for Identifying Buyers :- 
 		 - Offline 
 		 - Online 

Identifying Buyers Offline
	 - Sources to Find Buyers Offline
 		 - Participation in Exhibition / Trade Fairs – http://www.tradefairdates.com/ 
 		 - Databases from Govt. Trade Promotion Bodies - http://commerce.gov.in/DOC/index.aspx 
 		 - Help of Trade Magazines / News Paper 
 		 - List of Trade Directories World Wide 
 		 - Yellow Pages - http://www.yellowpages.com/ 

	 - Indian Embassy Abroad “OUR FIRST RELATIVE” - http://www.indiaonlinepages.com/indian-embassies-abroad.html
 		 - Support Provided By Indian Embassy
 				 - 1. List of Buyers / Concern Associations
 				 - 2. List of Important Govt. Departments 
 				 - 3. List and Authentication of Documents Provided by Importers
 				 - 4. Verification of Buyers 
 				 - 5. Support for any Trade Disputes 
 				 - 6. Details of Trade Agreements

		 - Keep in Mind before sending Emails to any Indian Embassy:
 				 - To Contact their Commerce Department
 				 - No attachments – As their Email Accounts are Sensitive

		 - Personal Visits

Identifying Buyers Online
	 - B2B Websites/ Portals 
 		 - www.alibaba.com 
 		 - www.tradeindia.com 
 		 - www.indiamart.com 
 		 - www.fiber2fashion.com 
 		 - www.exportersindia.com 

	 - List of Top B2B Websites Worldwide -http://dragon-guide.net/ 

How to Find Online Buyers
	 - Search For 
 		 - Trading Companies 
 		 - Try to find Distributors 
 		 - Trade Agents 
 		 - Find the list of Companies Registered as a Manufacturer of your used Products 
 		 - Search for Importers List 

	 - Authenticated Directories 
 		 - Trade Associations Directories in Targeted Countries 
 		 - Exhibition / Trade Fairs Exhibitors Directory - http://www.tradefairdates.com/ 
 		 - Local Chamber of Commerce in your Targeted Countries 

Importance of Communication
	 - Reach to the Right Person 
 		 - Difficulties you will face to reach the right Person 
 				 - Non English Communication on Reception – Use of Google Translate
 				 - Not Transfer of call to the Purchase Department 
 				 - Use of Social Networking Websites 
 		 - Important Points require to be consider before starting the Communication 
 				 - Visit Companies Website 
 				 - Understand about their Products 
 				 - List out Matching Products 
 		 - How to Communicate 
 				 - Start Communication with Right Reference 
 				 - Create the Interest of the Buyer to know more about you 
 				 - Be clear in Communication 
 				 - Don’t give Lengthy Description of your Company 
 				 - Don’t forget to take Direct Number & Email address of the Concern Person 
 		 - How to Write an Email 
 				 - Clear Attention 
 				 - Draft an Email with Clear Reference 
 				 - Content or Message should be Short & Clear 
 				 - Don’t send your detailed Companies Profile instead link your website 
 				 - Don’t send Photographs or Brochures in First Email 
 				 - No Grammatical Mistakes 
 				 - Use Google Translate 
 				 - Use of Google Analytics 
 		 - Points to be Considered before sending Samples 
 				 - Use Covering Letter 
 				 - Packaging of the Samples 
 				 - Prepare Pro-forma Invoice showing “SAMPLES FOR EVALUATION PURPOSE NOT FOR SELL” 

Genuinity of Buyers
	 - How to Verify Genuine Buyer (Buyer Authentication) 
 		 - Visit Companies website and Membership Details with Any Associations 
 		 - Ask for Govt. Registration Documents 
 		 - Take Support from Indian Embassy 
 		 - Check Credit Reports 

What is Online Marketing?
	 - Online marketing refers to a set of powerful tools and methodologies used for promoting products and services through the Internet. 
 	 - Online marketing includes a wider range of marketing elements than traditional business marketing due to the extra channels and marketing mechanisms available on the Internet.
 	 - Online marketing can deliver benefits such as: 
 		 - Growth in potential 
 		 - Reduced expenses 
 		 - Elegant communications 
 		 - Better control 
 		 - Improved customer service 
 		 - Competitive advantage 
 	 - Online marketing is also known as Internet marketing, Web marketing, digital marketing and search engine marketing (SEM).

 	 11. Releasing Cargo from Shipping Lines/ Air Lines

INCOTERMS
	 -Importance of INCOTERMS
 				 - Port of Loading
 				 - Port of Destination
 	 - Types of INCOTERMS
 				 1. Ex Works – Cost Up to Factory
 				 2. FOB – Free On Board – Cost Up to Port of Loading
 				 (Cost Up to Factory + Local Transportation + Custom Clearance Charges)
 				 3. C&F / CFR / CNF – Cost & Freight – Cost Up to Port of Destination
 				 (FOB + Shipping Line / Airline Freight Charges Up to Port of Destination)
 				 4. CIF – Cost Insurance & Freight –
 				 (C&F + Insurance Charges)
 				 5. DDU – Delivery Duty Unpaid –
 				 (CIF + Import Clearance Charges at Port of Destination)
 				 6. DDP – Delivery Duty Paid –
 				 (Door Delivery Charges without Import Duty)

Modes of transportation
Why Exports?
	 - Increases the sales and profits of company,
 	 - Enables company to benchmark with their competitors and know their strategies and what they have done to increase their market share globally,
 	 - Reduces the risk of market fluctuations by depending on many markets,
 	 - Diminishes unit cost by adopting mass production strategy,
 	 - Enhances firms and countries’ competitive advantage by gaining new technologies,
 	 - Support countries' balance of trade.

What are Incoterms?
	 - The term, Incoterms, is an abbreviation for International Commercial Terms.
 		 They are a common set of rules which define the responsibilities of sellers and
 		 buyers for the delivery of goods under sales contracts for domestic and international trade.
 	 - Initially created in 1936 by the International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) and have been periodically revised (Incoterms 2010 is the 8th revision)

International Commercial Terms History
	 - Initially created in 1936 by the International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) and have been periodically revised (Incoterms 2010 is the 8th revision)
 	 - Incoterms are generally good for approximately 10 years ~ not a magic number, but historically about accurate
 	 - Incoterms reflect world-wide trade practices, as practices change, Incoterm are revised
 	 - Incoterms 2010 were written by the ICC, represented by 8 individuals from various countries/areas of the world
 				 - Met 11 times in person
 				 - Received over 2000 suggestions in first request
 				 - Refined suggestions over 4 proposals
 				 - Controlling source document is written in British English and will be translated into 35+ languages over the next year.

What are Incoterms ® 2010?
	 - Eleven (11) Incoterms® 2010 (used to be 13 terms)
 				 - Four (4) terms were deleted and two (2) new terms were created
 	 - Incoterms® 2010 begun on January 1, 2011
 	 - Available worldwide through 100 International Chamber of Commerce National Committees
 				 - The terms aren’t law; no laws that require their use and are not all inclusive
 				 - Country neutral – they don’t favor one country over another
 				 - Self-contained – all information that determines responsibility and risk are in one place

Key Definitions
	 What is Delivery?
 				 - As defined in Incoterms®,
 					 “it is used to indicate where the risk of loss of or damage to the goods passes from the seller to the buyer.”
 	 It is not always:
 				 - When the goods arrive in your customer’s hands or
 				 - When the goods leave your dock
 				 - Defined the same in all countries
 	 You must know your contract and your Incoterm®
 				 - Note: A Purchase Order and a matching Acknowledgement will constitute a “contract” if there isn’t a separate stand-alone contract related to the transaction.
 	 Pre-carriage: inland transportation on the seller’s side
 				 - Domestic: from the place where the shipment starts to any subsequent transportation carriage
 				 - International: from the place where the shipment starts to the departure point on the seller’s side

Transportation Definitions
	 Pre-carriage: inland transportation on the seller’s side
 				 - Domestic: from the place where the shipment starts to any subsequent transportation carriage
 				 - International: from the place where the shipment starts to the departure point on the seller’s side
 	 Main Carriage:
 				 - Domestic: subsequent transportation beyond pre-carriage
 				 - International: transportation from the point of departure on the seller’s side to the arrival pint on the buyer’s side
 	 On-carriage:
 				 - Domestic: subsequent transportation beyond main carriage
 				 - International: transportation from the arrival pint on the buyer’s side
 	 Transhipment
 				 - Transshipment or transhipment is the shipment of goods or containers to an intermediate destination, then to yet another destination.
 	 Door – to – Door
 				 - Contract of carriage that includes pre-carriage, main-carriage and on-carriage by the same carrier
 	 Door – to – (Air) Port:
 				 - Contract of carriage including pre-carriage and main-carriage to airport or ocean port or truck terminal port or rail port
 	 (Air) Port – to – (Air) Port:
 				 - Contract of carriage for main carriage only
 	 (Air) Port – to – Door:
 				 - Contract of carriage including main carriage and on-carriage

Types of Risk
	 - PRODUCT RISK – Covered with Insurance
 	 - FOREIGN EXCHANGE RISK
 	 - CREDIT RISK – Payment Risk

PRODUCT RISK - INSURANCE
	 - Basics of insurance
 				 - Types of Risk involved to Product
 				 - Understanding International Clauses

 	 - Institute Cargo Clause “A”
 				 - All Risks Cover

 	 - Institute Cargo Clause “B”
 				 -Intermediate Cover
 				 - Earthquakes, Volcanic Eruptions or Lighting
 				 - Washing Overboard
 				 - Entry of Water in to the vessel, hold, conveyance, container or place of storage
 				 - Total Loss of any package lost overboard or dropped during loading and unloading operation

 	 - Institute Cargo Clause “C”
 				 - Minimum Cover
 				 - How & when to Book Insurance
 				 - Why 110% of Invoice Value
 				 - Why Claims are Always Payable at Destination
 				 - Understanding Clauses of Insurance under L/C
 				 - Claim Formalities & Procedure under Various Circumstances
 				 - Damage to the Cargo
 				 - Theft

CREDIT RISK – PAYMENT RISK

	HVD INTERNATIONAL “worldwide Export – Import – Representatives” company of agricultural commodities. From procurement to delivery HVD INTERNATIONAL, is actively taking care in all aspects of the phase. Our mission is to provide the essence of the agro resources to International Market.


	We are pleased to introduce ourselves as one of the leading Export Import Representatives from the Mother of Agro Land – India.


	We offer our sincere efforts and services to make a bridge between buyers and suppliers that helps them in running their business smoothly and profitably. We have sources for all kinds of agriculture commodities from all major countries of the World. i.e., India, Nigeria, Ethiopia, Sudan, Mozambique, Tanzania, Togo, Mali, Burkina Faso, Vietnam, Thailand, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Morocco, Argentina, Bolivia, Paraguay, Venezuela, Mexico, Bulgaria and China.


	Our back bone and strengths include our leading suppliers from across the globe. They deliver quality products and hard core services, all time easy availability and accessibility, timely response to our clients and value their time.


	 We strives customer through our proffessional and quality services and having ability to sustain professionalism through the work. 
 	 we dont say but our work and success show what we are now.
 	 We ensure the highest levels of certainty and satisfaction through a deep-set commitment to our clients, comprehensive industry expertise and a global network of innovation and delivery centers.
 	 we believe our responsibility extends beyound business.

Product Selection
	 - Proper selection of the commodity market is an important factor before starting an import. Commodity market data and information collected during research helps to prepare the commodity market report. The right market can be selected by answering the following the following questions. 
 	 - Is the product(s) an importer need to conducting his business available domestically? 
 	 - Is there a lucrative and untapped domestic market for an imported product? 
 	 - Does importing a product increase competitiveness as a business? 

Categories of Imports
	 - Freely Importable Items 
 		 - As the name suggests the items under this category are free to be imported and do not require any License. 
 	 - Canalised Imports 
 		 - Items under this category can be imported only through specified channels or Government agencies. 
 	 - Restricted / Licensed Imports 
 		 - Items under this category are restricted and require License for importation. 
 	 - Prohibited Items 
 		 - As the name suggests the items under this category are NOT permitted to be imported at all. 
 	 - Note: List of items under above categories are published in the Foreign Trade Policy. Importer / Exporter must have IEC (Importer Exporter Code) issued by DGFT (Director General Of Foreign Trade, Government of India).
Govt. Bodies
	 - Ministry of Commerce and Industry 
 	 - DGFT 
 	 - Customs and Excise 
 	 - State Trading Enterprise 

Registration of Importers
	 - Following documents are required for Registering with Customs 
 	 - IEC License 
 	 - Bank Ad code letter 
 	 - Proof of payment / remittance through Importer’s Bank 
 	 - Balance sheet of previous year 
 	 - Copy of Income tax return/ Vat or sales tax returns filed 
 	 - Pan Card 
 	 - Previous Bill of Entry (In case this is not the first time) 
 	 - KYC Document / Importers Profile 

Identification of Supplier
	 - Information on overseas supplier can generally be obtained from the following sources : 
 		 - As the name suggests the items under this category are free to be imported and do not require any License. 
 		 - Trade Directories and Yellow Pages in origin countries 
 		 - Embassies of trade representing countries in India and Abroad
 		 - Friends and relatives in foreign countries 
 		 - International Trade Promotion Organization, International Trade and Exhibitions. 
 		 - Various trade promotion council 
 		 - Indenting Agents of foreign suppliers 
 		 - Visiting popular websites 
 		 - Newsletters by various Export Promotion Councils, Commodity Boards, Authorities and Apex Chambers. 
 		 - State Trading Enterprises 
 		 - Seller’s representing office 

Verifying Genuineness
	 - Banks 
 	 - Indian Embassies abroad 
 	 - Credit Information Agencies for specific commercial information
 	 - Trade Information Centres of origin country posted in India 
 	 - Overseas Suppliers Agents in India

Finalizing the Terms of Import
	 - Call for samples 
 	 - Catalogues 
 	 - Other relevant literatures 
 	 - Specifications of the items to be imported 
 	 - Samples brought in India as personal baggage by bona fide commercial travellers and businessmen or imported by post or by air shipment are exempt from the customs duty. 

Important aspects of Import Contract
	 - Product, Standards and Specifications 
 	 - Quantity 
 	 - Inspection
 	 - Total Value of the Contract 
 	 - Terms of Delivery e.g., type of packaging, replacement of defective goods, etc 
 	 - Taxes, Duties and Charges 
 	 - Period of Delivery / Shipment : Time, Place of delivery etc.,
 	 - Packing, Labelling and Marking 
 	 - Terms of Payment – Amount, Mode and Currency
 	 - Discounts and Commissions 
 	 - License and Permits
 	 - Insurance 
 	 - Documentary Requirements 
 	 - Guarantee
 	 - Non-performance of Contract 
 	 - Remedies 
 	 - Arbitration and Dispute Resolution

Payment Formalities
	 - Importer should be conversant with pricing and the manner of payment. The Importer should know the meaning of the technical definition. Please refer such terms as defined under International Chamber of Commerce “INCO TERMS”. These terms have universal acceptance.

Mode of Settlement
	 - Generally following mode of settlement are carried out : 
 		 - Advance 
 		 - Payment against Documentary Collection 
 		 - Payment under Letter of Credit 
 	 - Advance payment : 
 		 - AD-1 Category, AD-II and AD-III categories. Advance payment can only be made through AD-1 category.
 		 - All payments must be collected against imports through authorised banks in current account, as mentioned above. 
 		 - Currency of Invoicing : Indian Rupee or foreign currency. 

On site Inspection
	 - In order to ensure exact quantity and quality (as per specification) of cargo is shipped out, one can also appoint Inspection agencies like SGS, Intertek, CIG etc can be approached to conduct survey and submit you report before shipment is carried out. You can also insist on sealing by such inspection agencies to ensure no pilferage is done. 

Follow up with Shipper
	 - Follow up with shipper and also check online tracking of cargo on internet, shipping line on ETA, etc.

	 - Do's 
 		 - Open LC or import transactions only for customers and open only if the party has got sanction limit. Allow import of restricted items as per procedure laid down in the Exim Policy. Handover import documents only to drawee or his PA holder against property acknowledgement. Allow payment for import by debit to customer’s account. Allow payment for the bills beyond six months and also allow payment of overdue interest on sight bills for a period not exceeding six months. Allow payment to local agents on commission basis. In case of overseas agent, allow commission as per FEMA guidelines. Verify the imported items under the LC. Issue amendments to LC only on the basis of written request. Verify whether the payment method in Letter of Credit is done as per FEMA guidelines or not. In case of default payment, crystallise the bill on 10th day of the month. Open LC or import transactions only for customers and open only if the party has got sanction limit. Allow import of restricted items as per procedure laid down in the Exim Policy. Handover import documents only to drawee or his PA holder against property acknowledgement. Allow payment for import by debit to customer’s account. Allow payment for the bills beyond six months and also allow payment of overdue interest on sight bills for a period not exceeding six months. Allow payment to local agents on commission basis. In case of overseas agent, allow commission as per FEMA guidelines. Verify the imported items under the LC. Issue amendments to LC only on the basis of written request. Verify whether the payment method in Letter of Credit is done as per FEMA guidelines or not. In case of default payment, crystallise the bill on 10th day of the month. 
 	 - Don'ts
 		 - Issue the Letter of Credit if the customer doesn’t have IEC number.
Open LC without proper transport documents. Allow advance payment without proper documentation. Forward the documents to third party without permission from the importer. Import prohibited or restricted items without import license. Allow direct remittance of import bills beyond the limit and without EC copy of bill of entry. Open revolving LC without safety clause. Amendments to the Letter of Credit for import of those items which is either restricted or prohibited. Allow import documents received under collection paid without verifying importers line of business and financial standing. 

Procedures on Customs Clearance
	 - Vessel Arrival 
 	 - Filing of BOE 
 	 - Filing of BOE
 	 - Noting Date 
 	 - Examination 
 	 - Payment of Duty 
 	 - License Department
 	 - Appraisal 
 	 - OOC 
 	 - Delivery of Goods
 	 - FIRST CHECK – Examination is done at the Appraisement level. Cargo should be opened only in presence of Customs officer.

Upon Cargo Arrival, the Importer has two options:
	 - •To Clear immediately, or • To Store under Bond and clear later 
 	 - BONDED WAREHOUSING
 		 - Cargo is stored in Bonded Warehouse and cleared later on payment of import duty. 
 		 - Bonded warehousing charges will be applicable during the period of storage. 
 	 - CLEARANCE FOR HOME CONSUMPTION
 		 - Cargo is cleared for delivery on payment on applicable duties.
 		 - Importer takes delivery of his cargo and no storage charges are applicable, if delivery is taken during such free period.

How to calculate Assessable Value
	 - a. Ex-Works : This is the value of the goods at the factory gate at origin 
 	 - b. FOB (Free on Board) : This value is the ex-works value + charges at origin upto loaded on vessel / aircraft. Such origin charges include local transportation, customs clearance charges and handling at origin port / airport 
 	 - c. C & F (Cost & Freight) : This value comprises of the FOB value + air / ocean freight upto the airport / port of discharge. This value does not include the landing charge at the port of destination. 
 	 - d. CIF (Cost Insurance Freight) : This value comprises of the FOB value + air / ocean freight upto the airport / port of discharge + insurance cost for insurance of the goods upto the country of destination. The value does not include the landing charge at the port of destination. 
 	 - e. Assessable Value : The customs duty in India is charged on the assessable value which is 1.01 CIF value. A standardized 1% landing charges are added to the CIF value for arriving at the assessable value. If any local commissions are payable by the importer to the indenting agent, such commissions are also to be added for arriving at the assessable value. Assessable value is calculated after converting the foreign currency CIF value into Indian Rupee at the current customs notified exchange rate. 

	 - If the air freight amount is not ascertainable or if the actual air freight is more than 20% of FOB, then 20% of FOB is considered as air freight for calculation of CIF value. 
 	 - If insurance cost is not available, standard insurance charges equivalent of 1.125% of FOB value are considered by Indian Customs for calculation of CIF price 

INCOTERM
	 - Technical Terminology used by Importers 
 		 - Ex-work 
 		 - Free on Rail (FOR)/Free on Truck (FOT) 
 		 - Free Alongside Ship (FAS) 
 		 - Free on Board (FOB) 
 		 - Cost and Freight (C & F) 
 		 - Cost Insurance Freight (CIF) 

Documents to be submitted by Importers
	 - Commercial Invoice / Exporter’s Invoice 
 	 - Packing List 
 	 - Bill of lading / Delivery order 
 	 - GATT declaration 
 	 - Letter of Credit 
 	 - Certificate of Origin 
 	 - Import Licence
 	 - End user certificate 
 	 - High seas sales certificate etc 
 	 - Catalogue 
 	 - Insurance Certificate

Commercial Invoice
	 - Invoice is the prime document in any business transactions. Invoice is one of the documents required for import customs clearance for value appraisal by concerned customs official. Assessable value is calculated on the basis of terms of delivery of goods mentioned in commercial invoice produced by importer at customs location.. The concerned appraising officer verifies the value mentioned in commercial invoice matches with the actual market value of same goods. This method of inspection by appraising officer of customs prevents fraudulent activities of importer or exporter by over invoicing or under invoicing. So Invoice plays a pivotal role in value assessment in import customs clearance procedures. 

Import General Manifest
	 - The shipping line has to give a detailed report of all the goods on board in a report known as "Import General Manifest" 
 	 - Import manifest is required to be submitted before arrival of aircraft or vessel 
 	 - Grant of Entry Inwards by Customs Officer 

Bill of lading / AWB
	 - BL/AWB is one of the documents required for import customs clearance. 
 	 - Bill of lading under sea shipment or Airway bill under air shipment is carrier’s document required to be submitted with customs for import customs clearance purpose. Bill of lading or Airway bill issued by carrier provides the details of cargo with terms of delivery. 

Import License
	 - As I have mentioned above, import license may be required as one of the documents for import customs clearance procedures and formalities under specific products. This license may be mandatory for importing specific goods as per guide lines provided by government. Import of such specific products may have been being regulated by government time to time. So government insist an import license as one of the documents required for import customs clearance to bring those materials from foreign countries. 

Insurance Certificate
	 - Insurance certificate is one of the documents required for import customs clearance procedures. Insurance certificate is a supporting document against importer’s declaration on terms of delivery. Insurance certificate under import shipment helps customs authorities to verify, whether selling price includes insurance or not. This is required to find assessable value which determines import duty amount. 

Purchase Order/Letter of Credit
	 - Purchase order is one of the documents required for import customs clearance. A purchase order reflects almost all terms and conditions of sale contract which enables the customs official to confirm on value assessment. If an import consignment is under letter of credit basis, the importer can submit a copy of Letter of Credit along with the documents for import clearance. 

Catalogue
	 - Technical write up, literature of imported goods or any other similar documents may be required as one of the documents for import clearance under some specific goods. For example, if a machinery is imported, a technical write up or literature explaining it’s function can be attached along with importing documents. This document helps customs official to derive exact market value of such imported machinery in turn helps for value assessment. 

Industrial License
	 - An industrial license copy may be required under specific goods importing. If Importer claims any import benefit as per guidelines of government, such Industrial License can be produced to avail the benefit. In such case, Industrial license copy can be submitted with customs authorities as one of the import clearance documents. 

RCMC. Registration cum Membership Certificate
	 - For the purpose of availing import duty exemption from government agencies under specific goods, production of RCMC with customs authorities is one of the requirements for import clearance. In such cases importer needs to submit Registration Cum Membership Certificate along with import customs clearance documents. 

Pre-shipment Inspection / Test Report
	 - It is the practice of employing specialized private companies to check shipment details. Analysis certificate/MSDS incase of Chemicals, Mill Test Certificate in case of Metal, Catalogue/Write up for plant, machinery and spares
 	 - PSI helps to: 
 		 - Detect over-invoicing to prevent unjustified transfer of foreign exchange abroad; 
 		 - Determine the classification and valuation of goods; and 
 		 - Ensure the correct collection of import duties and taxes by Customs authorities

BILL OF ENTRY
	 - It is a document certifying that the goods of specified description and value are entering into the country from abroad.
 	 - The Bill of entry-different copy meant for different purposes with different color. 
 	 - Bill of Entry for home consumption: 
 	 - Bill of Entry for Warehouses 
 	 - Bill of Entry for Ex-Bond Clearance 

DEEC/DEPB /ECGC or any other documents for duty benefits
	 - If importer avails any duty exemptions against imported goods under different schemes like DEEC/DEPB/ECGC etc., such license is produced along with other import clearance documents.

GATT/DGFT declaration
	 - As per the guidelines of Government of India, every importer needs to file GATT declaration and DGFT declaration along with other import customs clearance documents with customs. GATT declaration has to be filed by Importer as per the terms of General Agreement on Tariff and Trade.

Manufacturer Certificate
	 - CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN
 	 - CERTIFICATE OF WEIGHT 
 	 - CERTIFICATE OF QUALITY 
 	 - CERTIFICATE OF INSPECTION 

IMPORT RISK
	 - Transport Risk –loss of goods during transportation. 
 	 - Quality Risk –final quality of the products. 
 	 - Delivery Risk –goods are not delivered on time. 
 	 - Exchange Risk –the change in the value of currency. 

DOCUMENTS REQUIRED FOR EPCG LICENCE & EXPORT OF DEFECTIVE PARTS Following documents are required for preparing CE certificate for EPCG licence of Govt. of India:
	 - 1.Scanned copies of PAN and IEC 
 	 - 2.Website address of applicants if available 
 	 - 3. CA certificate certifying last 3 years exports , if available 
 	 - 4.Details of export products , to which capital goods , which have to be imported are related 
 	 - 5.Step wise flow chart specifying clearly as to where the capital good to be imported , will be utilized 
 	 - 6.Brief justification of quantity of capital goods required to be imported and whether there is process/production requirement of quantity 

Following documents are required for preparing CE certificate for exporting part/equipment for repairs and return after repairs
	 - 1.EXPORT INVOICE of part/equipment being sent for repairs ; export invoice must state name of capital good of which this part belongs, serial number/identification number of part/equipment and Bill of entry for home consumption details of capital good 
 	 - 2.IMPORT INVOICE of capital good of which the part/equipment has become defective 
 	 - 3.Bill of entry for home consumption of capital good 
 	 - 4.Any E mails exchanged with the repairers
